oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Roman Cathedral, circa 1859
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A page from a mounted and bound volume of twenty-five pen-and-ink wash drawings, and two pen-and-ink maps of Nashville created by William A. Eichbaum during the 1850s. Eichbaum was a Nashville bookseller and resident for fifty years. This drawing is of St. Mary's Catholic Church, the first Roman-Catholic Cathedral in Tennessee. St. Mary's was designed by William Strickland, architect for the Tennessee State Capitol. The edifice was erected in the Greek Revival style at Summer Street (now Fifth Avenue) and Cedar Street (now Charlotte Street) in 1844. During the Civil War, this church was converted into a hospital. Forms part of the William A. Eichbaum Sketchbook. 1 drawing : col. ; 5.75 x 9 in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Eichbaum, William A., 1787-1873--Notebooks, sketchbooks, etc.
St. Mary's Church (Nashville, Tenn.)
